Bell Retiring From Coaching Basketball at C-M

After 31 years of coaching high school basketball, the past 18 years at Canon-McMillan, Rick Bell has decided to retire.

Bell, who led the Big Macs to their first appearance in the WPIAL semifinals this past season, compiled a career record of 428-316 (.575 winning percentage) – which included 13 seasons at Peters Township.

Under Bell, Canon-McMillan set a single-season record of 21 wins in the 2017-2018 season.

In the past five seasons, the Big Macs compiled a 74-45 record and qualified for the WPIAL and PIAA playoffs three times.

“Rick runs one of the best programs, from top to bottom, that I have been around,” said Frank Vulcano, Jr., Canon-McMillan’s athletic director. In my five years at Canon-McMillan, Rick has taken this program to heights that have never been seen in school history.

“He has been a great mentor to all of his assistants and a great role model to his players throughout his years.”

Bell had a 223-103 record at Peters Township.

We look forward to restoring the area following all necessary protocols, including safety inspections.

Canon-McMillan High School to Host Financial Aid Events

Canon-McMillan High School officials have announced two upcoming financial aid information events slated for October.

Charlene Bedillion, director of financial aid at Washington & Jefferson College, will be the keynote speaker at Canon-McMillan High School’s Financial Aid Night from 6 p.m. to 8 p.m. Oct. 3 in the Canon-McMillan High School Atrium.

Topics to be covered include an overview of financial aid and scholarship resources. Canon-McMillan parents and students in 11th and 12th grade are invited to attend.

Then from noon to 5 p.m. Oct. 6, a representative from PHEAA will be at Canon-McMillan High School library to assist parents in completing the Free Application for Federal Student Aid.

Families may secure an appointment by registering online at: http://signup.com/go/cUgxkUi.

If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact the counseling department at wrubleskim@cmsd.k12.pa.us.

Is Throwback Monday a thing? We're making it one today! Throwback to last month's Colonial Days at Cecil Intermediate.

Here's what you need to know:

Cecil Intermediate students donned period clothing and participated in myriad arts and crafts during the school’s Colonial Day event this past school year.

On May 4, students played colonial games and learned about everything from butter churning to one-room school houses.

They also got an opportunity to learn about different kitchen tools used during colonial times, design hex signs and make silhouettes and hornbooks.

Throughout the all-day event, students also rotated throughout stations demonstrating 18 th Century ttrades.

But that’s not all: Students were also treated to a presentation by Mr. Clay Kilgore—a blacksmith and historical re-enactor—of the Washington Historical Society, who brought in many items and spoke about the different trades people needed in colonial times.

Congratulations to Wylandville Elementary School, which was recently selected as one of five 2016 Carton to Garden Elementary Award winners for the second-annual Carton 2 Garden Contest.

The contest, sponsored by Evergreen Packaging and KidsGardening.org, is focused on helping to facilitate teachable moments through hands-on educational experiences in a garden setting and strives to provide educators with an opportunity to teach students about environmental stewardship, recycling, and re-purposing materials.

“Your project exemplifies our mission to better care for our planet through upcycling and recycling,” contest judges said.

For winning, Wylandville will receive an award package valued at more than $1,000.

It includes:

- A $900 cash prize for soil, plans and other gardening needs

- A $100 gift certificate from the Gardener’s Supply Co.

- A Garden Essentials Educational Package
